title: Chapter 10 – Sets and Basic Data Operations Checkpoint
description: Quick concept-check for chapter 10. Test your understanding of sets, uniqueness, union, intersection, and how sets compare to lists.

questions.prompt: What is a set in Python?

options.label: A list that is always sorted.
A collection of unique elements with no guaranteed order.
A dictionary with only one key.

explanations.overview: Sets store unique elements and do not keep a fixed order.

byOptionId.a: Lists can be sorted, but that is not what sets are.
byOptionId.b: Correct – this is the main idea of a set.
byOptionId.d: Dictionaries store key–value pairs, which is different from sets.

questions.prompt: Which line correctly creates a set of file names?

explanations.overview: Sets use curly braces {} with comma-separated elements.

byOptionId.a: This is a list, not a set.
byOptionId.b: This is a tuple, not a set.
byOptionId.c: Correct – this creates a set of two file names.
byOptionId.d: This is one long string, not a set.

explanations.overview: Converting a list to a set removes duplicate values.

byOptionId.a: This is the original list, not a set.
byOptionId.c: Correct - only unique values remain in the set.
byOptionId.d: Tuples are a different type that does not remove duplicates automatically.

questions.prompt: You have `a = {1, 2}` and `b = {2, 3}`. What is `a & b` (the intersection)?

explanations.overview: Intersection keeps only elements that appear in both sets.

byOptionId.a: That would be the union (all elements from both).
byOptionId.b: 1 is only in set a, not in both.
byOptionId.c: Correct - 2 is the only element in both sets.
byOptionId.d: There is at least one common element, so it's not an empty set.

questions.prompt: Which statement about sets and lists is true?

options.label: Lists remove duplicates automatically, sets do not.
Sets keep the order of elements, lists do not.
Both sets and lists allow duplicate elements.
Sets keep only unique elements, lists can have duplicates.

explanations.overview: Lists and sets both store collections, but handle duplicates differently.

byOptionId.a: Lists allow duplicates; sets remove them.
byOptionId.b: Lists keep order; sets do not guarantee order.
byOptionId.c: Only lists allow duplicates; sets do not.
byOptionId.d: Correct - this is the key difference for duplicates.
